text:
I'm looping over a text file and pushing parsed lines to a `Dict{String, Vector{Vector}}` and I find I need a function similar to `push!`, but that creates the key in the dict if it does not already exist. I came up with
```function push_or_add!(d::AbstractDict{K, <: AbstractVector}, p::Pair) 
    haskey(d, p[1]) ? push!(d[p[1]], p[2]) : push!(d, p[1] => [p[2]])
end```
which works, but it performs the key lookup twice, once in `haskey` and once in `push!`. Is there a simple way of doing this already existing?

text: I'm not sure if the `get!` method actually lets me do what I want. I want to push to the vector no matter if the key exist or not. `get!(fun, ...)` only pushes if there is no key already, otherwise it only `get`s

elements.text: method actually lets me do what I want. I want to push to the vector no matter if the key exist or not.
only pushes if there is no key already, otherwise it only `get`s

text:
Actually, it returns the inner vector which is efficient to push to, so the following works
```function push_or_add!(d::AbstractDict{<:Any, <: AbstractVector}, p::Pair) 
    i = p[2]
    vec = get!(d, p[1]) do
        push!([i])
    end
    vec[end] === i || push!(vec, i)
end```

elements.text: Actually, it returns the inner vector which is efficient to push to, so the following works

function push_or_add!(d::AbstractDict{<:Any, <: AbstractVector}, p::Pair) 
    i = p[2]
    vec = get!(d, p[1]) do
        push!([i])
    end
    vec[end] === i || push!(vec, i)
end
